hero.headline: Don't Let Partnership Conflict Kill Your Startup
hero.subheadline: Free alignment mapping for co-founders. Eight critical domains. One honest conversation. Before lawyers get involved.
hero.supporting: Harvard Business School research shows 65% of high-potential startups fail due to co-founder conflict. Most founding teams never discuss the fundamentals—until it's too late. Partnership Mapping helps you align on what matters before you build.

problem.headline: You're Building on Unstable Ground
body: The best time in your business is before you start building—when it's all blue skies and big dreams. As soon as the rubber meets the road, you're in for conflict. The problem isn't disagreement itself. It's that you've never explicitly aligned on:

10% of co-founders end their relationship within a year. An additional 45% break up within four years. Up to 43% of founders ultimately buy out their co-founder due to interpersonal rifts and power struggles.
The tragedy? Most of these failures were preventable. The conflicts that destroy partnerships don't emerge from nowhere—they grow from unspoken assumptions made in those early, optimistic days.

cost.headline: What Partnership Conflict Actually Costs
body: It's not just about hurt feelings. Venture capitalists scrutinise the dynamic between co-founders just as much as a startup's idea. A business plan and customer base can change, but a founding team doesn't.
When a co-founder leaves early, it reduces the startup's success odds by nearly two-thirds. Even amicable splits are painful. The recovery is slow. The damage is real.

The root cause? Most founders unfortunately don't have the awareness or openness to take care of their partnership once they start experiencing tension. They must learn how to embrace conflicts and disagreements as a source for brainstorming and collaborative thinking.

solution.headline: Align Before You Sign
solution.body: Partnership Mapping is a free facilitation tool that guides co-founders through structured alignment across eight critical operational domains. No lawyers required. No complex jargon. Just honest answers.

steps.title: 1. Individual Assessment (15 minutes)
steps.body: Each co-founder privately answers questions across eight domains—from equity ownership to exit mechanisms. You'll see three proven approaches for each domain and select which ones you'd support.

steps.title: 2. Conflict Identification (Automatic)
steps.body: The system shows you exactly where you align and where you don't. No guessing. No avoiding. Just clarity.

steps.title: 3. Facilitated Resolution (Your Timeline)
steps.body: One partner drives a review session. You discuss gaps, add comments, and negotiate until everyone approves. The tool tracks progress and keeps everyone accountable.

steps.title: 4. Blueprint Delivery (Instant)
steps.body: Once aligned, you receive a comprehensive blueprint documenting your agreements. This becomes the foundation for your operating agreement—before you spend money on solicitors.

domains.headline: What You'll Align On
domains.intro: Partnership Mapping covers the eight domains that matter most for new partnerships:

items.title: 1. Equity Ownership (0°)
items.body: Who owns what percentage, and why? Equal split, weighted by capital, or weighted by role?

items.title: 2. Capital Contribution (45°)
items.body: How do future investments work? Equal requirements, initial credit, or sweat equity conversion?

items.title: 3. Time/Effort Expectation (90°)
items.body: What's everyone committing? Equal hours, asymmetric roles, or outcome-based?

items.title: 4. Compensation Structure (135°)
items.body: How do partners get paid? No salary, market rate, or founder salary?

items.title: 5. Profit Distribution (180°)
items.body: How do profits flow? Proportional to equity, equal regardless, or tiered?

items.title: 6. Decision Authority (225°)
items.body: Who decides what? Unanimous consensus, delegated domains, or managing director model?

items.title: 7. Voting Control (270°)
items.body: How much does each vote count? Proportional, equal, or domain-specific?

items.title: 8. Exit Mechanism (315°)
items.body: What happens when someone leaves? Book value, revenue multiple, or shotgun clause?

domains.closing: Operating agreements formalise the business relationship, reduce the risk of misunderstandings, clarify responsibilities, and provide built-in processes for resolving disagreements. But they're expensive to create—and worthless if you haven't aligned first.

items.title: Prevent the 65%
items.body: When everyone is aligned and has the same story in their minds, it makes for quicker decision-making and better execution because those decisions are being made by people who believe they're working towards something meaningful.

items.title: Save Thousands in Legal Fees
items.body: Solicitors draft better agreements when you arrive with clear answers. Partnership Mapping gives you those answers—for free.

items.title: Build on Solid Ground
items.body: Having clearly defined roles prevents misunderstandings and ensures each partner is aware of their obligations. No surprises. No assumptions. Just documentation.

items.title: Attract Better Investment
items.body: Without a solid partnership agreement, your business could raise eyebrows amongst investors, lenders, and potential clients. Having an agreement shows stakeholders that your business is operating with a clear understanding of responsibilities, liabilities, and expectations.

items.title: Sleep Better
items.body: You'll know exactly what happens if someone wants out, gets ill, or just stops showing up. Addressing unforeseen scenarios ensures the business can continue to operate even in tragic events.

sections.title: Who We Are
sections.body: Outkomia is an agency that matches outcomes to opportunity. We specialise in helping organisations—from sports federations to emerging companies—understand what they're actually trying to achieve, then connect those outcomes to the resources that make them possible. Partnership Mapping grew from our own experience. When we structured our agency partnerships, we discovered that existing tools focused on documents, not alignment. We needed something that forced honest conversations before contracts. So we built it. Then we made it free.

sections.title: Our Philosophy
sections.body: Outcomes before outputs. Clarity before contracts. Alignment before agreements. When partnerships work, it's because everyone knows what they're building, why they're building it, and what happens when things change. Partnership Mapping helps you get there.

sections.title: The Company Behind the Tool
sections.body: NxtStride Finland Oy operates a sports technology ecosystem, but we started where you are now—as co-founders who needed to align. We've built TitleStream, Sports Veritas, and Outkomia Agency. We've navigated equity splits, compensation models, decision authority, and exit mechanisms. Partnership Mapping reflects what we wish we'd had when we started: a structured way to surface assumptions, test alignment, and document agreements before they became problems.

sections.title: Why We Made This Free
sections.body: We're a small company. We know what it's like to watch every euro. We know legal fees feel impossible when you're just starting. We know how many partnerships fail because founders couldn't afford proper advice early. This tool won't replace solicitors. But it will make you better prepared when you get there.

sections.title: Our Commitment
sections.body: Partnership Mapping will remain free. We won't sell your data. We won't upsell you. We won't pitch you consulting services. We just want more small companies to succeed. Because when founders align early, everyone wins.

finalCta.headline: Don't Be Part of the 65%
finalCta.body: 65% of high-potential startups fail due to conflict amongst co-founders. You can't eliminate conflict. But you can align before it destroys what you're building.

solutions.name: Equal Split
solutions.description: Every partner owns the same percentage. It does not matter how much money someone invested or how many hours they worked. This is simple and can feel fair because everyone is treated as equally important. The risk is that if one person later puts in much more time or takes more financial risk, they may feel it is unfair.

solutions.name: Weighted by Capital
solutions.description: Ownership is based on how much money each partner invests. If someone puts in more cash, they get a larger share. This protects people who take more financial risk. The downside is that it can undervalue the partner who brings time, skills, and experience instead of cash.

solutions.name: Weighted by Role
solutions.description: Ownership is based on how important each person’s role and skills are for the business. People doing the most critical work or bringing rare expertise get a larger share. This rewards contribution quality, not just money or hours. The hard part is agreeing what roles matter most, and roles can change over time.

solutions.name: Equal Ongoing Requirements
solutions.description: Whenever the business needs more money, everyone must invest the same amount. For example, if the company needs €30,000 and there are three partners, each pays €10,000. This keeps financial power balanced. The risk is that not everyone will have the same access to cash when needed.

solutions.name: Initial Investment Credited Forever
solutions.description: Money invested at the start always counts as a permanent credit. If you put in €50,000 at launch, that credit stays when you later compare ownership or profit shares. This protects early risk-takers. The downside is that it may not match who keeps funding the business later.

solutions.name: Sweat Equity Conversion
solutions.description: Time and work can be treated like an investment, not only cash. Work hours get a euro value and are counted as contributions. This helps partners who have skills but not money. The hard part is agreeing the value of an hour and tracking time in a consistent way.

solutions.name: Equal Full-Time Commitment
solutions.description: Every partner agrees to work the same number of hours per week, often 40+ hours. This makes the workload feel balanced and reduces the chance that someone feels used. The downside is that life changes, and equal hours do not always mean equal impact.

solutions.name: Asymmetric Roles with Defined Percentages
solutions.description: Partners agree that different roles need different time levels. One person might do 50% time while another does 100%. Expectations are written clearly as percentages. This adds flexibility, but it can create conflict if people disagree about whether someone is meeting their commitment.

solutions.name: Outcome-Based, No Time Tracking
solutions.description: Partners focus on results, not on hours. If your responsibilities are completed well, it does not matter when you work. This gives freedom and keeps attention on what matters. It needs clear goals and can fail if partners have different standards for what “good” looks like.

solutions.name: No Salary, Profit Distribution Only
solutions.description: Partners do not take a regular wage. Money is paid out only when the business makes profit, using an agreed split. This keeps more cash inside the business. The downside is that partners need savings or other income, which can favor partners with more personal money.

solutions.name: Market-Rate Salary Plus Profit Share
solutions.description: Each partner is paid a normal market salary for their job, like they would earn elsewhere. After that, any profits are shared separately. This helps partners pay bills, but many new businesses cannot afford market salaries and it reduces money available for growth.

solutions.name: Founder Salary Below Market Plus Profit Share
solutions.description: Partners take a lower salary (for example 50–70% of market rate) and later make up the difference through profit sharing. This balances personal needs and business cash. It requires short-term sacrifice and assumes profit will eventually arrive.

solutions.name: Proportional to Equity
solutions.description: Profits are shared based on ownership percentage. If you own 40%, you receive 40% of profits. This is simple and matches profit to ownership risk. The downside is that it may not reflect who is currently doing the most work.

solutions.name: Equal Regardless of Equity
solutions.description: Profits are split equally between partners, no matter who owns more shares. This can reward current effort and build unity. The downside is that it separates profit from ownership, which can feel unfair to someone who invested more money or took higher risk early on.

solutions.name: Tiered: Salary First, Then Proportional Residual
solutions.description: Partners first receive their agreed salaries. Then the remaining profit is split based on ownership percentages. This gives baseline income before profit sharing. The downside is extra complexity: you must define what counts as salary and manage two different formulas.

solutions.name: Unanimous for Material Decisions
solutions.description: Big decisions require everyone to agree. Examples are large spending, hiring, strategy changes, or investments. This protects minority partners and increases buy-in. The downside is that disagreements can slow everything down and the business can get stuck.

solutions.name: Delegated by Domain
solutions.description: Each partner has final say in their own area of responsibility. This speeds up decisions and respects expertise. The risk is that boundaries can be unclear, and one person’s decision may impact another person’s work or budget.

solutions.name: Managing Director Model with Final Say
solutions.description: One partner has the final say when agreement cannot be reached. Others give input, but this person decides. This prevents deadlock and creates accountability. The downside is possible resentment if the leader ignores others or makes repeated poor decisions.

solutions.name: Proportional to Equity
solutions.description: Voting power matches ownership percentage. If you own 45%, your vote counts as 45%. This aligns control with financial risk. The downside is that smaller owners may feel powerless, especially on decisions that affect daily work.

solutions.name: Equal Regardless of Equity
solutions.description: Each partner gets one vote with equal weight, no matter ownership. This keeps power balanced and prevents one person from dominating. The downside is that it can feel unfair if one person owns much more of the company.

solutions.name: Domain-Specific Expert Decides
solutions.description: For a given topic, the partner with the most expertise has the deciding vote. This can speed up decisions and use the right knowledge. The downside is defining clear boundaries and making sure experts still listen to others.

solutions.name: Book Value Buyout
solutions.description: When someone leaves, they sell their shares based on the company’s book value (assets minus debts). This uses real numbers and is easy to explain. The downside is that book value often undervalues a growing business because it ignores future potential and brand value.

solutions.name: Revenue Multiple Formula
solutions.description: The exit price is based on a simple formula: annual revenue times an agreed multiple (for example 2× or 3×). This can reflect business momentum. The downside is that revenue does not always mean profit, and revenue can drop quickly.

solutions.name: Shotgun Clause
solutions.description: One partner names a price for the whole company. The other must choose to buy or sell at that price. This pushes the price to be fair. It works best with two partners and can be harder to apply when there are three or more partners.
